name: Basel
fun_fact: Fun fact: Basel sits at the tri-border area where Switzerland, France, and Germany meet - you can literally have breakfast in Switzerland, lunch in France, and dinner in Germany, all within a 15-minute tram ride.

hero_dishes.name: Basler L√§ckerli
hero_dishes.description: Spiced honey cookies with almonds, hazelnuts, candied citrus, and a hint of kirsch cherry liqueur - crisp outside, chewy inside
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dating back centuries, these Christmas cookies became Basel's signature year-round treat. The recipe balances cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg with honey and local kirsch. Jakob's Basler Leckerly has made them since 1753 - the oldest company in Basel.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Jakob's Basler Leckerly (St. Johanns-Vorstadt 47 - operating since 1753), L√§ckerli-Huus (established 1903, the unofficial official version), Confiserie Bachmann

hero_dishes.name: Basler Mehlsuppe (Flour Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Dark roux soup that's far more complex than the name suggests - rich, hearty, and unique to Basel
hero_dishes.origin_story: This soup is a Basel icon born from Basler Fasnacht (carnival) marking the start of Lent. The dark roux gives it depth and character. It represents Basel culture so strongly that it's served year-round in traditional Beizen (taverns) and especially during the famous three-day carnival.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Guild house restaurants (Zunfth√§user) - Schl√ºsselzunft on Freie Strasse and Safran Zunft on Gerbergasse, traditional Swiss Beizen throughout the city

hero_dishes.name: Sour Liver (Saure Leber)
hero_dishes.description: Liver cooked in a tangy wine-vinegar sauce with onions, a Basel bistro fixture
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional dish reflects Basel's location at the Rhine crossroads - German influences meet Swiss precision. The sour sauce balances the richness of liver. It's been a staple in Basel bistros and guild taverns for generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Guild house restaurants (Zunfth√§user), Schl√ºsselzunft, Safran Zunft, traditional Beizen

hero_dishes.name: Seasonal Swiss Specialties
hero_dishes.description: Cheese fondue, raclette, and seasonal game dishes prepared with Basel's tri-cultural influences
hero_dishes.origin_story: Basel's position at three borders creates unique culinary fusion. Swiss cheese traditions meet French elegance and German heartiness. Guild houses serve these specialties with authentic atmosphere and formal service.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Guild house restaurants for traditional Swiss meats and seasonal game, Rhine riverside restaurants for summer terraces

signature_drinks.name: Kirsch (Cherry Liqueur)
signature_drinks.description: Clear cherry brandy that's a key ingredient in Basel's famous L√§ckerli cookies
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as a digestif after meals or used in baking. This Swiss specialty appears in both sweet and savory Basel dishes. The cherry orchards of the region have supplied kirsch for centuries.

signature_drinks.name: Swiss Wine
signature_drinks.description: Local wines from nearby regions, often lesser-known varieties that rarely leave Switzerland
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Guild houses and riverside restaurants serve Swiss wines that most foreigners never taste - production is small and locals drink most of it. Paired thoughtfully with seasonal Swiss dishes.

food_culture_notes: Basler Fasnacht (carnival) traditions dictate seasonal eating - Mehlsuppe during carnival, Fastenw√§he (pretzel-shaped pastry) and Magenbrot (soft gingerbread) at autumn fair
Guild houses (Zunfth√§user) that once housed medieval trade guilds are now open to public - dining in these historic buildings offers authentic Basel atmosphere
Summer brings Rhine riverside terrace dining - locals float down the river in waterproof bags (Rhine swimming is a beloved tradition)
Basel's position at three borders means menus often feature German, French, and Swiss influences on the same plate
